column13: editors/emacs: Fix build w/ gcc50 and C-x C-f browser.
column20:
Prevent calloc() optimization (just as for csh in base).
Also fix reports by emacs users that file viewer fails on special filenames.
Turns out emacs is very relying on ls having --dired flag support (gnu ls).
So if it fails it fallbacks to regexes on ls -l output that results in some
unselectable file entries.
Fix it by adding new option that uses gls from coreutils cause even swildner
doesn't like idea of adding --dired support in base ls. From gls(1):
-D, --dired
generate output designed for Emacs' dired mode
In case of GNULS=off, base ls is used, it works for standard filenames
(no whitespaces, special symbols or complicated symblinks --> ../../bin/../file)
so just enforce LC_TIME=C for ls -l invoke to ease up output for dodgy regexes.

column13: Fix shm permission problem of rspamd on DragonFly
column20:
Rspamd tried to call shm_open(3) with a path in the root filesystem
(e.g. /rhm.3f0fd440d46fac91e1b4). Obviously, this fails due to wrong
permissions, and in effect this makes rspamd very slow and probably it
cannot perform it's job (spam filtering) at all.
Lots of lines like the following were found in
/var/log/rspamd/rspamd.log before this patch:
rspamd_shmem_mkstemp: /usr/obj/dports/mail/rspamd/rspamd-1.4.1/src
  /libutil/util.c:1970: failed to create temp shmem
  /rhm.3f0fd440d46fac91e1b4: Permission denied

This patch fixes the problem by creating the shm files in /tmp. With
this patch applied, these lines are gone from the log.

This is a long standing debate.  So people feel the opposite that I do (but they're wrong!).

column13: graphics/inkscape: Add ${PREFIX}/lib/inkscape to ldconfig search path.
column20:
This fixes the problem with graphics/inkscape not finding lib/inkscape/libinkscape_base.so.
The problem is that although inkscape is linked with rpath, the linking options are wrong. In addition to
-Wl,-rpath,"$ORIGIN/../lib/inkscape:/usr/local/lib"
they should also contain -Wl,-z,origin:
-Wl,-rpath,"$ORIGIN/../lib/inkscape:/usr/local/lib" -Wl,-z,origin
Thanks to zrj for pointing this out. I verified that it produces a working binary; it adds "(FLAGS)              ORIGIN" and "(FLAGS_1) Flags: ORIGIN" to the binary. So the proper solution would be to add a patch upstream.
However, I ran a quick test and it appears that DragonFly differs from FreeBSD and Linux in that the latter two do not need to set "FLAGS" and "FLAGS_1" in the binary. ORIGIN in rpath is parsed w/o the flags set.
Should DragonFly follow FreeBSD and Linux in this? It'd reduce the number of patches we need.
Background: similar discussion on FreeBSD and libreoffice. It does not apply any more though since FreeBSD does not care of whether FLAGS, FLAGS_1 is set.
https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=54015

column21:
Yes, that's true. I was too cryptic, let me elaborate.
The root of the issue is that DragonFly behaves differently from both FreeBSD and Linux with respect to how $ORIGIN is handled. DragonFly needs "-Wl,-z,origin" at linking so that "(FLAGS) ORIGIN" and "(FLAGS_1)  Flags: ORIGIN" are set in the binary. If the latter are set, $ORIGIN is expanded correctly; if not, $ORIGIN is not expanded and the shared library is not found. The requirement that the latter two flags are needed in order for $ORIGIN expansion seems standard behavior; or at least it was standard at some point.
However, FreeBSD and Linux do not care if "(FLAGS) ORIGIN" and "(FLAGS_1)  Flags: ORIGIN" are set in the binary. I.e. even if they are not set, $ORIGIN in rpath or runpath is still expanded correctly and the shared library is found. I tested this with a small example found in the thread above
https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=54015
This is the reason inkscape fails to start on DragonFly but not on FreeBSD. I installed inkscape on FreeBSD and tested that it runs fine. The inkscape header on FreeBSD reads:
% readelf -d /usr/local/bin/inkscape | grep ORIGIN
.... RPATH  Library rpath: [$ORIGIN/../lib/inkscape:/usr/local/lib]
.... RUNPATH  Library runpath: [$ORIGIN/../lib/inkscape:/usr/local/lib]
I do not know why FreeBSD and Linux behave so.
It is correct that ld.bfd and ld.gold do not differ with respect to "-Wl,-z,origin". Both need this explicitly in order that "(FLAGS)" etc be in the binary on DragonFly. The difference is that with "MAKE_ENV+= LDVER=ld.bfd", the required "-Wl,-z,origin" is added in the linking phase. Question: why are those flags added with ld.bfd?
(As a side, compiling with "-Wl,-z,origin" on FreeBSD results in a binary where "(FLAGS)" and "(FLAGS_1)" are just empty. Compiling with "-Wl,-z,origin,-rpath" as suggested in the libreoffice thread above yields empty fields too. No idea how to correctly set "(FLAGS)" etc on FreeBSD. But then it does not matter, FreeBSD does not care anyway.)
All in all it might not be a good idea to fix this using LDVER=ld.bfd. One could have used LDFLAGS+= "-Wl,-z,origin", this explicitly shows the fix. The result is the same, the "(FLAGS)" etc are set correctly and inkscape runs fine.
In light of this, there are at least three options:
(1) USE_LDCONFIG+= ${PREFIX}/lib/inkscape,
(2) LDFLAGS+= "-Wl,-z,origin",
(3) LDVER=ld.bfd
What's the best option to use?
The general question is whether or not DragonFly might want to align the behavior with respect to $ORIGIN with Linux/FreeBSD?

column21:
The general idea is that we want to decouple our input.h from FreeBSD since we can only use the input.h that our kernel agrees with. So the choice's are as follows:
(1) use our input.h etc that we have exported at /usr/include/compat/linux. This entails we have to patch ports with sth like
-I/usr/include/compat
in order that includes of the form
#include <linux/input.h>
work.
(2) Or we can fake, i.e. make our own copy of evdev-proto whose content (input.h, input-event-codes.h) will be taken from our tree. Then we do not need patches like the ones in (1) on top of the ones that FreeBSD already have for input.h
(3) Or we go with FreeBSD's evdev-proto. This will lead to many headaches down the road since our kernel interface might not be in sync with what FreeBSD/Linux have.
Option (1) was the initial one we came up with. But now I realize that perhaps (2) is also possible, and at least at first sight needs less patching than (1).
One issue that will come up (but that will come up with all approaches) is dependency problem. Port A may require that libinput be not less than X.Y, but our lower stack (our input.h) might yet not support that.

/usr/include/compat/linux/input.h
/usr/include/compat/linux/input-event-codes.h
to
/usr/local/include/linux
What FreeBSD are doing is downloading Linux's versions of those files and copying them to /usr/local/include/linux
We do not have uinput.h since we do not have the corresponding functionality in the kernel. It could be ported from FreeBSD if necessary.

exists or not. For instance, it may suddenly happen that a number of applications start to build since they find /usr/include/linux/input.h and happily assume things we do not have in place yet. column13: Fix EGL Window creation and prevent GLFW-Wayland from SEGFAULTING
column20:
These are fixes that I needed to apply in order for glfwCreateWindow() to stop SEGFAULTING, with the main culprit being EXT_image_dma_buf usage, despite not being supported.
The patches allow window creation on sway, with Mesa 18.3.2 and newer. However, due to EXT_KHR not being properly used, the window remains blank with Mesa 18.3.2, even though a context is successfully created. Proper EXT_KHR extension use was fixed at some point and with Mesa 20.2.0-devel (git-412e29c277) at the latest, window and context creation works without issue.
All patch files were diffed against Mesa 20.2.0-devel (git-412e29c277).

Actually, this commit removes a pkg-plist patch that was not taking them into account.
The message on sting was

===> Checking for items in STAGEDIR missing from pkg-plist
Error: Orphaned: /sbin/e2fsck

And as these files were in reality present

% ls -l /build/buildbase/SL00/construction/sysutils/e2fsprogs/stage/sbin/
total 1544
-r-xr-xr-x  1 root  wheel  778536 Nov 11 13:30 e2fsck
-r-xr-xr-x  1 root  wheel    7480 Nov 11 13:30 fsck_ext2fs`

We're now taking them into account again.
